classifications.note: Alpha decay: ⁴He emission, discrete energies, heavy nuclei (A>150). Beta decay: β⁻ (n→p+e⁻+ν̄), β⁺ (p→n+e⁺+ν), EC (p+e⁻→n+ν). Continuous energy spectrum. Gamma decay: electromagnetic transition between nuclear states. Discrete energies. Internal conversion: alternative to gamma emission. Q-value = mass difference. Conservation: energy, momentum, angular momentum, parity.

principles.statement:
Radioactive decay involves the spontaneous transformation of unstable nuclei through various processes, each governed by specific mechanisms and conservation laws: Alpha Decay: Emission of alpha particles (helium-4 nuclei) from heavy nuclei: $^A_ZX ightarrow ^{A-4}_{Z-2}Y + ^4_2	ext{He}$. Characteristics: Discrete energy spectrum (monoenergetic); Occurs primarily in heavy nuclei (A > 150); Q-value: $Q_\alpha = [m(X) - m(Y) - m(\alpha)]c^2$; Explained by quantum tunneling through Coulomb barrier; Geiger-Nuttall law relates decay constant to alpha energy. Beta Decay: Three types that transform neutrons and protons: Beta-minus (β⁻): $n ightarrow p + e^- +  ar{
u}_e$, $^A_ZX ightarrow ^A_{Z+1}Y + e^- +  ar{
u}_e$; Beta-plus (β⁺): $p ightarrow n + e^+ + 
u_e$, $^A_ZX ightarrow ^A_{Z-1}Y + e^+ + 
u_e$; Electron Capture (EC): $p + e^- ightarrow n + 
u_e$, $^A_ZX + e^- ightarrow ^A_{Z-1}Y + 
u_e$. Characteristics: Continuous energy spectrum (shared between electron and neutrino); Requires neutrino hypothesis to conserve energy and angular momentum; Governed by weak interaction; Q-value determines maximum electron energy. Gamma Decay: Emission of high-energy photons from excited nuclear states: $^A_ZX^* ightarrow ^A_ZX + \gamma$. Characteristics: Discrete energy lines; Follows electromagnetic selection rules ($\Delta I = 0, \pm 1$, no 0→0); Competing process: internal conversion (direct electron ejection). Internal Conversion: Alternative to gamma decay where excitation energy is transferred directly to an atomic electron: $^A_ZX^* ightarrow ^A_ZX + e^-$. Creates characteristic electron lines and X-rays. Decay Energy and Q-values: The Q-value is the energy released in decay: $Q = [m(	ext{parent}) - m(	ext{daughters})]c^2$; Must be positive for spontaneous decay; Determines decay rates and particle energies. Conservation Laws: All decays conserve: Energy (including rest mass energy); Linear and angular momentum; Electric charge; Nucleon number; Lepton number (in beta decay). The different decay modes allow nuclei to move toward stability by adjusting their proton-neutron ratio, mass, and excitation energy.
principles.application: Write decay equations for various nuclides. Calculate Q-values for decay processes. Predict decay modes from nuclear properties. Analyze energy spectra. Apply conservation laws to decay kinematics. Understand decay mechanism selection.
principles.example: Uranium-238 alpha decay: ²³⁸U → ²³⁴Th + α + 4.27 MeV. Carbon-14 beta decay: ¹⁴C → ¹⁴N + e⁻ + ν̄ + 0.156 MeV. Technetium-99m gamma decay: ⁹⁹ᵐTc → ⁹⁹Tc + γ + 0.143 MeV.
principles.analogy: Like different ways a shaky tower can collapse - alpha decay is like throwing out a large block (big mass change); beta decay is like rearranging bricks (changing neutron/proton ratio); gamma decay is like settling vibrations (releasing excitation energy); each method moves the tower toward a more stable configuration

worked_examples.title: Alpha Decay Calculation
worked_examples.problem: Calculate for ²³⁸U alpha decay: (a) Q-value, (b) Daughter nucleus, (c) Alpha particle energy. Masses: ²³⁸U=238.050788 u, ²³⁴Th=234.043601 u, ⁴He=4.002603 u.

step_by_step.explanation: Alpha decay: Z decreases by 2, A decreases by 4. ²³⁸U (Z=92) → ²³⁴Th (Z=90)
E_α = Q × (A-4)/A = 4.270 × 234/238 = 4.197 MeV (recoil gives rest to daughter)
Measured alpha energy = 4.196 MeV, excellent agreement. Discrete lines confirm monoenergetic emission.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Q=4.270 MeV, (b) ²³⁴Th, (c) E_α=4.197 MeV. Demonstrates alpha decay calculation.

image.caption: Alpha decay energy calculation and kinematics

worked_examples.title: Beta Decay Analysis
worked_examples.problem: Analyze ¹⁴C beta decay: ¹⁴C → ¹⁴N + e⁻ + ν̄. Masses: ¹⁴C=14.003242 u, ¹⁴N=14.003074 u. Find: (a) Q-value, (b) Maximum electron energy, (c) Compare with spectrum.

step_by_step.explanation: Δm = m(¹⁴C) - m(¹⁴N) = 14.003242 - 14.003074 = 0.000168 u (electron masses cancel in atomic masses)
E_max = Q = 0.156 MeV (when neutrino gets zero energy)
Continuous spectrum from 0 to 0.156 MeV. Average energy ~Q/3 = 0.052 MeV.
Measured endpoint energy = 0.156 MeV, confirming Q-value. Continuous spectrum requires neutrino.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Q=0.156 MeV, (b) E_max=0.156 MeV, (c) Continuous spectrum 0-0.156 MeV. Shows beta decay characteristics.

sections.introduction: Mathematical description of radioactive decay, exponential decay law, half-life concepts, and calculations involving decay rates and activities.

key_concept.definition: Decay kinetics: Exponential decay law, Decay constant λ, Half-life t₁/₂, Mean lifetime τ, Activity A, Decay rate, Decay probability, Statistical nature, Large number limit, Decay calculations.
key_concept.context: Radioactive decay follows statistical exponential kinetics, with the decay constant and half-life characterizing the decay rate of radioactive substances.

image.caption: Exponential decay law and half-life concepts

classifications.value: Classification based on mathematical descriptions of decay rates
classifications.behavior: Different parameters describe decay kinetics: decay constant gives probability per time; half-life is practical time measure; mean lifetime is statistical average; activity measures decays per second; each parameter can be converted to others; all describe the same exponential process

classifications.note: Decay law: N(t) = N₀e^(-λt). Activity: A(t) = λN(t) = A₀e^(-λt). Half-life: t₁/₂ = ln2/λ ≈ 0.693/λ. Mean lifetime: τ = 1/λ. Relationship: t₁/₂ = τ ln2. Units: activity in becquerel (Bq) or curie (Ci). 1 Bq = 1 decay/s, 1 Ci = 3.7×10¹⁰ Bq.

principles.statement: Radioactive decay follows exponential kinetics governed by quantum mechanical probabilities and statistical behavior of large numbers of atoms: Fundamental Decay Law: The rate of decay is proportional to the number of radioactive atoms present: $\frac{dN}{dt} = -\lambda N$, where λ is the decay constant. Integration gives the exponential decay law: $N(t) = N_0 e^{-\lambda t}$. This describes the number of atoms remaining at time t. Activity: The activity A is the decay rate: $A(t) = -\frac{dN}{dt} = \lambda N(t) = A_0 e^{-\lambda t}$, where A₀ = λN₀. The SI unit is becquerel (Bq) = 1 decay per second. The traditional unit is curie (Ci) = 3.7 × 10¹⁰ Bq. Half-Life: The half-life t₁/₂ is the time for half the atoms to decay: $N(t_{1/2}) = \frac{N_0}{2} = N_0 e^{-\lambda t_{1/2}}$. Solving gives: $t_{1/2} = \frac{\ln 2}{\lambda} = \frac{0.693}{\lambda}$. After n half-lives, the fraction remaining is (1/2)ⁿ. Mean Lifetime: The mean lifetime τ is the average time until decay: $\tau = \frac{1}{\lambda}$. The relationship is: $t_{1/2} = \tau \ln 2$. Statistical Nature: Decay is random and statistical for individual atoms; The exponential law emerges from large numbers; The probability that a specific atom decays in time dt is λdt; This quantum randomness is fundamental, not due to measurement limitations. Decay Calculations: Common problems include: Finding remaining activity after given time: $A = A_0 (1/2)^{t/t_{1/2}}$; Time for activity to reach certain level: $t = t_{1/2} \frac{\ln(A_0/A)}{\ln 2}$; Determining original activity from current measurement; Mixed source activities. Applications of Kinetics: Radiometric dating (¹⁴C, K-Ar, U-Pb); Medical dosimetry and treatment planning; Nuclear power fuel management; Environmental monitoring; Scientific research using tracers. The exponential decay law is one of the most fundamental and accurately verified relationships in physics, applicable whenever processes occur at rates proportional to the amount remaining.
principles.application: Solve decay problems using exponential law. Calculate half-lives from decay data. Determine activities at different times. Convert between different time parameters. Analyze decay of mixed sources. Apply to dating and dosimetry problems.
principles.example: Carbon-14: t₁/₂=5730 years, λ=ln2/5730=1.21×10⁻⁴ yr⁻¹. After 1000 years, fraction remaining = (1/2)^(1000/5730)=0.885. Iodine-131: t₁/₂=8.02 days, used in medicine. After 1 week, fraction remaining = (1/2)^(7/8.02)=0.543.
principles.analogy: Like a crowd leaving a stadium randomly - each person has a constant probability per minute of deciding to leave; initially many leave quickly; as crowd thins, fewer leave per minute; the half-life is when half have left; the exponential law perfectly describes this random departure process

image.caption: Radioactive decay kinetics and mathematical relationships

worked_examples.title: Half-Life Calculations
worked_examples.problem: A sample has initial activity 800 Bq. After 2 hours, activity is 200 Bq. Find: (a) Decay constant, (b) Half-life, (c) Activity after 6 hours, (d) Time for 90% decay.

step_by_step.explanation: 90% decay means 10% remaining: 0.10 = e^(-λt), ln(0.10)=-λt, t=-ln(0.10)/λ=2.303/0.693=3.32 hours
3.32 hours ≈ 3.32 half-lives, (1/2)^3.32=0.10, correct.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) λ=0.693 h⁻¹, (b) t₁/₂=1.00 h, (c) A(6h)=12.5 Bq, (d) t(90%)=3.32 h. Demonstrates decay calculations.

worked_examples.title: Radiocarbon Dating
worked_examples.problem: Ancient wood sample has ¹⁴C activity 6.5 Bq/g. Fresh wood has 13.5 Bq/g. ¹⁴C t₁/₂=5730 yr. Find: (a) Age of sample, (b) Fraction remaining, (c) Uncertainty implications.

step_by_step.explanation: Typical ¹⁴C dating uncertainty ~±40 years. Assumes constant ¹⁴C production, no contamination.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Age=6050 years, (b) Fraction=0.481, (c) Uncertainty ~±40 years. Demonstrates radiocarbon dating.

principles.principle: Radioactive Decay Series and Practical Applications
principles.statement: Radioactive decay occurs in series where unstable parent nuclides decay through chains of daughters to stable endpoints, with numerous practical applications: Natural Decay Series: Four natural series exist from primordial nuclides: Uranium Series: ²³⁸U → ²⁰⁶Pb (8 alpha, 6 beta decays); Thorium Series: ²³²Th → ²⁰⁸Pb (6 alpha, 4 beta decays); Actinium Series: ²³⁵U → ²⁰⁷Pb (7 alpha, 4 beta decays); Neptunium Series: ²³⁷Np → ²⁰⁹Bi (extinct naturally). Each series has characteristic mass numbers: A=4n (Thorium), A=4n+2 (Uranium), A=4n+3 (Actinium). Secular Equilibrium: When a very long-lived parent (t₁/₂ >> daughter's t₁/₂) decays through short-lived daughters, secular equilibrium is established: $A_{daughter} = A_{parent}$ (activities equal). The Bateman equations describe the complete time evolution of all species in a decay chain. This equilibrium is used to extract daughter activities from natural sources. Medical Applications: Diagnostics: Gamma emitters (⁹⁹ᵐTc, ¹²³I) for imaging; Positron emitters (¹⁸F, ¹¹C) for PET scanning; Therapy: Beta emitters (⁹⁰Y, ¹³¹I) for cancer treatment; Brachytherapy: implanted sources (¹²⁵I, ¹⁰³Pd). Industrial and Research Applications: Radiography: ¹⁹²Ir, ⁶⁰Co for weld inspection; Tracers: ³H, ¹⁴C for biological and chemical studies; Thickness gauging: beta sources for manufacturing control; Sterilization: ⁶⁰Co for medical equipment. Dating Methods: Radiocarbon: ¹⁴C (t₁/₂=5730 yr) for archaeology; Potassium-argon: ⁴⁰K→⁴⁰Ar (t₁/₂=1.25×10⁹ yr) for geology; Uranium-lead: ²³⁸U→²⁰⁶Pb for oldest rocks; Fission track: uranium fission damage in minerals. Nuclear Power and Weapons: Fission reactors use ²³⁵U, ²³⁹Pu chain reactions; Breeder reactors convert ²³⁸U to ²³⁹Pu; Nuclear weapons use rapid chain reactions. Safety and Environmental Applications: Smoke detectors: ²⁴¹Am alpha sources; Luminescent signs: ³H, ¹⁴⁷Pm; Environmental tracers: studying ocean currents, groundwater flow. The understanding and application of radioactive decay has revolutionized medicine, transformed archaeology and geology, provided clean energy, and enabled numerous industrial processes, making it one of the most important phenomena in modern science and technology.
principles.application: Analyze decay chain kinetics. Calculate secular equilibrium conditions. Select appropriate isotopes for applications. Design radioactive dating methods. Understand medical isotope properties. Apply radioactivity to industrial problems.
principles.example: Radon-222: from ²³⁸U series, t₁/₂=3.82 days, alpha emitter, health hazard in buildings. Technetium-99m: t₁/₂=6.01 h, gamma emitter, used in 80% of nuclear medicine. Carbon-14: produced cosmically, t₁/₂=5730 yr, used for dating organic materials up to 50,000 years.
principles.analogy: Like a multi-generation family business - the long-lived founder (parent nuclide) establishes the business; each generation (daughter) manages for a while then passes it on; eventually a stable heir (stable nuclide) inherits permanently; the business products (radiation) are used in various industries (applications); some branches are more productive than others

worked_examples.title: Secular Equilibrium Calculation
worked_examples.problem: In ²³⁸U series: ²³⁸U (t₁/₂=4.47×10⁹ yr) → ... → ²²⁶Ra (t₁/₂=1600 yr) → ... Find: (a) Time to reach equilibrium, (b) ²²⁶Ra activity from 1 g ²³⁸U, (c) Mass of ²²⁶Ra at equilibrium.

step_by_step.explanation: Secular equilibrium when t>>t₁/₂(daughter). For ²²⁶Ra (1600 yr), need ~10×1600=16,000 years to reach within 0.1% of equilibrium.
At secular equilibrium, A_Ra = A_U = 12.43 kBq
Tiny mass of radium but high activity. Explains why radium is hazardous despite small quantities.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) ~16,000 years, (b) A_Ra=12.43 kBq, (c) m_Ra=3.41×10⁻⁷ g. Demonstrates secular equilibrium.

image.caption: Secular equilibrium calculation in decay series

worked_examples.title: Medical Isotope Selection
worked_examples.problem: Compare medical isotopes: ⁹⁹ᵐTc (t₁/₂=6.01 h, γ=140 keV) and ¹³¹I (t₁/₂=8.02 d, β⁻=0.61 MeV, γ=364 keV). Analyze for: (a) Diagnostic imaging, (b) Thyroid therapy, (c) Radiation safety.

step_by_step.explanation: Short half-life (6 h): rapid clearance, lower dose; Gamma energy (140 keV): ideal for imaging (good detection, moderate penetration); No beta emission: pure gamma emitter for imaging; Used in 80% of nuclear medicine studies.

Longer half-life (8 d): persists in tissue for treatment; Beta emission (0.61 MeV): localized cell destruction; Gamma emission (364 keV): allows imaging and dose verification; Thyroid-specific uptake: targeted therapy.
⁹⁹ᵐTc: patients quickly become non-radioactive; ¹³¹I: requires radiation precautions for days; ¹³¹I gamma energy higher: more shielding needed; Both: require careful handling and disposal.
Diagnostics: ⁹⁹ᵐTc preferred (short half-life, ideal gamma); Therapy: ¹³¹I preferred (beta emission, tissue persistence); Combination: sometimes both used for diagnosis then treatment.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Diagnostics: ⁹⁹ᵐTc (short t₁/₂, ideal γ), (b) Therapy: ¹³¹I (β emission, longer t₁/₂), (c) Safety: ⁹⁹ᵐTc safer due to short t₁/₂. Shows medical isotope selection.

common_misconceptions: Believing half-life means half the radiation is gone
Thinking all radioactive materials are equally dangerous
Believing decay can be sped up or slowed down
summary: Radioactive decay involves the spontaneous transformation of unstable nuclei through alpha (helium nucleus emission), beta (electron/positron emission or electron capture), or gamma (photon emission) processes. Decay follows exponential kinetics N(t)=N₀e^(-λt) with characteristic half-life t₁/₂=ln2/λ. Activity A=λN measures decay rate in becquerels. Natural decay series (uranium, thorium, actinium) proceed through chains to stable endpoints, often reaching secular equilibrium. Applications include medical imaging and therapy (⁹⁹ᵐTc, ¹³¹I), radiometric dating (¹⁴C, K-Ar), nuclear power, industrial radiography, and scientific research using radioactive tracers. Understanding radioactive decay enables both beneficial applications and safe management of radiation hazards.
